Such defects as attached to the curriculum through which the youth of Rome wasmade to pass intbe days of Tacitus (Dant. chs. 30-33) were remedied and corrected, in his case, by the appreciative study, of the great models of former times, especially Cicero. Of this study the Drnlogue bears obvious traces, and nothing will strilre the reader so much, especially at first, as the studied resemblance which its style bears to that of the great orator. It was while Tacitus was full ofa generous enthu- siasm for Cicero and his contemporaries that he is represented as having listened to the conversation which the treatise embodies and expands3 and at the date at which it is supposed to have been written his style was still under the influence of his early studies and pursuits ¹. It was, in fact, still in what may be called its first stage. In all probability, Tacitus had modelled his earliest efforts at the bar, as nearly as was possible after such an interval, ou the oratory of Cicero and his great contern- poraries. It was this, no doubt, that drew Pliny to him, and led him to select his friend as an example to be followed 1. Their early association must have been partly, at least, based on a kindred sentiment ol reverence ior the past. Now it is a known fact that Pliny was one of Quintilian's pupils (Epp. ii. 14, 93 vi. 6, 3), and it is interesting to speculato on the probability that Tacitus too had come under the influence ol the great rhetorician. Quintilian had returned to Rome, from Spain, in the train of Galba, and probably lost little time³ in commencing the educational career with which his name bas ever since been so closely associated Tacitus may even have been one of his earliest pupils. Chronology seems to favour the supposition, and the numerous points of contact which exist between the two writers add to its probability. It may have

been from Quintilian himself that Tacitus imbibed that antipathy to mechanical methods and the tinsel ornaments of unreal disputation which

reveals itself inMessalla’s speeches, as well as that belief in the superiority of Cicero which he evidently shares with the same speaker. Quintilian's mission at Rome, then and afterwards, was to recall the literature of the day from the studied affectation and empty elegance thau were then held
